div.p:
This is not the first time that you have
been called upon by me to act as arbiter
elegantiarum & to decide our family
disputes on the rights and wrongs of the
English language.

And farther & especially to settle the
usages as to certain phrases, to deter
-mine determine whether they be such as are deem
-ed deemed exclusively Irish consequently vulgar,
or whether though they may not be
sanctioned by Johnson or Lowth
nor by any grammar nor any diction
-ary dictionary they may be thought naturalized
in England by long use among well-
bred people - & no more to be subject
to the brand of vulgarity nor to be
pursued by the hue & cry of Bad English.
Bad English - Irish Irish Irish!

The question was asked
"Did the bell ring?"
Instead of answer being made to this
question an objection was raised - It
was observed that the question should
have been "Has the bell rung?"
Did the bell ring" the objector thinks
is not English but Irish - The objector
does not found the objection upon the evi-
dent evident impossibility of the bell's signing
itself withouten hands" such an objection
would in truth attach equally to the
phrase "Has the bell rung."
which in strict grammatical propriety
ought to be Has the bell rungbeen rung?
But laying aside this last question for
the purist - the present objector con-
ceives conceives that the word didshould not
be used in this sentence or in similar
cases without reference to a fixed &
specified time past - as thus
Did the bell ring yesterday?
at two oclock?

The individual who gave occasion
to the discussion by the question charged
to - (Did the bell ring) holds to it never
-theless & conceives that the time past
is implied with sufficient definiteness &
need not in common parlance & for
the main purposes of speech i e to be
understood completely be marked by
added words --

Defendant farther conceives or
conceits that the question Did the
bell ring - might be asked in England
as well as in Ireland, & that it would not
in good company be pronounced to be
either bad English or good Irish
Defendant having nothing farther to say
says no more & here the argument & the
dispute together rest, awaiting the result
of reference. -

The parties it is to be understood it is
to be observed did not get to such high
words as did CollSibthorpe & the Lord
John Russell in a late debate in the
House of Commons. The objector did
not absolutely declare that the phrase
used by his opponent was "inconsistent
with common sense as well as English
grammar"

Nor did the defendant think proper
in reply to declare against learning
either grammar or common sense in
anything else from the Honble objector

-- Nor does the defendant brandish
high the British sword (or the Irish)
nor offer the satisfaction of a gentleman
for a fault in grammar nor proceed to the
military mode of cutting the gordian knot
which he cannot untie. On the contrary
both parties prefer having a recourse
to civil decision & agree to refer the
matter to a judge to whose practical
skill & theoretic knowledge in speaking
as well as writing the English language
they with perfect respect both equally
bow down --

Mr Rogers' decision is impatiently
though humbly awaited by the parties
who mean while refrain from touching
upon the question of bell ringing & abstain
from the use of the word did altogether.
div.closer:
Signed by order for her Self & company
ME

postscript.p:
PS. When bickering hot
To high words got
Break out at Galliorum
The golden rule
In every school
To push about the forum
If it were not beneath the dignity of the
author of the pleasures of Memory he is
requested to say if he know what is Galli-
-orum Galliorum -- whether it be a real name in
sober certainty or existing only in
the brain of those who are engaged in
pushing about the forum --
M E
